group.name: General
group.description:
Ember Application Framework, Version 2 (AFV2)

Synopsis: an Application Framework that can be setup to implement ZigBee-compliant devices from various public profiles or any proprietary application profile for which XML description of clusters and devices has been provided. This framework includes an implementation of the ZigBee Cluster Library, which allows building any ZCL-based device. The AppBuilder tool within Ember Desktop is intended to serve as a graphical interface for configuration of this framework for new application targets.



Buttons Used:

Note that the button mappings are configurable through AppBuilder's HAL Configuration tab, so you should consult your AppBuilder configuration to determine which GPIO each button (first and second) are mapped to and which are enabled.



Also note that FORM and JOIN activities below are implemented by the AFV2 "Network Find" plugin by default. If this plugin is disabled in your AppBuilder configuration, these actions rely on your application code implementing some or all of the functions listed in the Implemented Callbacks list for the Network Find plugin. The BIND action described below relies on the network's Coordinator node being built with the optional End Device Bind feature. (Check "Enable End Device Bind" in the Stack Configuration tab of AppBuilder to enable this.)

  • 1st Application Button: if not joined: FORM (if the device is capable of forming)

  • 1st Application Button: if joined: BIND (send ZDO end device bind request)

  • 2nd Application Button: if not joined: JOIN

  • 2nd Application Button: if joined: PERMIT JOINING

Serial baud rates, ports used:

Default baud rate is 115200 bps on UART1 for all devices.

This can be set to other baud rates using AppBuilder's HAL Configuration tab or by redefining EMBER_AF_BAUD_RATE.





Serial commands supported:

NOTE: Three different serial modes can used by AFV2 applications:



  • FULL - Supports all the commands listed below that pertain to the device. This mode uses the most flash. This mode is enabled by defining "ZA_CLI_FULL" and not defining "ZA_TINY_SERIAL_INPUT". This is the default for new AppBuilder configurations if not changed via the HAL Configuration tab.
  • MINIMAL - (Not supported on EZSP Host platforms.) Supports a subset of the commands listed below. It uses less flash than FULL mode and more flash than TINY mode. This mode is enabled by defining "ZA_CLI_MINIMAL" and not defining "ZA_TINY_SERIAL_INPUT"
  • TINY - (Not supported on EZSP Host platforms.) Saves the most flash and saves RAM over the MINIMAL and FULL modes. This mode supports only single character commands and does not provide all the functionality that the FULL CLI provides. This mode is enabled by defining "ZA_TINY_SERIAL_INPUT". TINY serial mode has been deprecated, and will be removed in a future version.



Tiny Serial commands: (Available only in TINY mode) (DEPRECATED)

  • i = Gives information about the local node.
  • f = Forms a network on channel TINY_SERIAL_CHANNEL(11) and panID TINY_SERIAL_PANID (0x00AB).
  • j = Attempts to join a network on channel TINY_SERIAL_CHANNEL(11) and panID TINY_SERIAL_PANID (0x00AB).
  • p = Permits join for 20 seconds.
  • l = Leaves network.
  • s = Prints the networking stack's statistics counters.
  • t = Sends a read time cluster time attribute command to the ZC.
  • b = Sends a read basic cluster version attribute command to the ZC.
  • k = Prints security keys.
  • c = Clears security keys.
  • a = Establish a pArtner link key with the node defined by the "partnerLinkKeyEui" array in app/framework/util/af-main-soc.c. User must define KEY_ESTABLISHMENT_ENDPOINT.




Minimal Serial commands: the top level commands listed below and any sub commands are supported in minimal CLI mode

  • bsend
  • debugprint (if debug printing for Application area is enabled)
  • keys
  • network
  • print
  • raw
  • send
  • send_multicast
  • version (if debug printing for Application area is enabled)
  • counters
  • help
  • reset
  • echo
  • info
  • s-update
  • libs (if debug printing for Application area is enabled)
  • zdo (if configuration enables serial commadns for sending ZDO messages)
  • custom (executes custom command included in the emberAfCustomCommands array of type EmberCommandEntry)

group.name: Global ZCL
group.description: All the ZCL global commands defined in the ZigBee Cluster Library Specification. These command line commands can be used to send messages over the air to, for instance, read and write attributes to devices on the network.

group.name: Test Harness
group.description: All commands related to the testing of a device.

group.name: Informational
group.description: The Informational command set provides commands for displaying information about the device. These commands include things like printing out the attribute tablerr

group.name: Network
group.description: The Network command set provides commands for interacting with the network. This includes building as well as sending ZigBee commands out on to the network.

group.name: Security
group.description: The Security command set includes all of the commands related to security configuration on the device.

group.name: Building and Sending Messages
group.description: Commands for building and sending messages out onto the network.

group.name: Attribute Management
group.description: Commands related to reading and writing attributes locally on a device.

group.name: ZigBee Network Management Commands (ZDO)
group.description: Commands related to the management of a ZigBee network including device discovery and commissioning.

command.description: Creates a global read command message to read from the cluster and attribute specified

arg.name: cluster
arg.description: The cluster id of the cluster to read from.

arg.name: attributeId
arg.description: The attribute id of the attribute to read.

command.description: Creates a global write command message to write to the cluster and attribute specified

arg.name: cluster
arg.description: The cluster id of the cluster to write to.

arg.name: attributeId
arg.description: The attribute id of the attribute to write.

arg.name: type
arg.description: The type of the attribute to write.

command.description: Creates a global write undivided command message to write to the cluster and attribute specified

arg.name: cluster
arg.description: The cluster id of the cluster to write to.

arg.name: attributeId
arg.description: The attribute id of the attribute to write.

arg.name: type
arg.description: The type of the attribute to write.

command.description: Creates a global write command message to write to the cluster and attribute specified

arg.name: cluster
arg.description: The cluster id of the cluster to read from.

arg.name: attributeId
arg.description: The attribute id of the attribute to read.

arg.name: type
arg.description: The type of the attribute to write.

command.description: Creates discovery message for devices with the associated cluster and attribute specified.

arg.name: cluster
arg.description: The cluster id of the cluster to discover.

arg.name: attributeId
arg.description: The attribute id of the attribute to read during discovery.

arg.name: max
arg.description: Max number of discovery responses.

command.description: Creates a global read reporting command for the associated cluster, attribute and server/client direction.

arg.name: cluster
arg.description: The cluster id to read from.

arg.name: attributeId
arg.description: The attribute id to read from.

arg.name: direction
arg.description: 0 for client-to-server, 1 for server-to-client.

command.description: Creates a global send me a report command for the associated values.

arg.name: cluster
arg.description: The cluster id of the requested report.

arg.name: attributeId
arg.description: The attribute id for requested report.

arg.name: dataType
arg.description: The two byte ZigBee type value for the requested report.

arg.name: minReportTime
arg.description: Minimum number of seconds between reports.

arg.name: maxReportTime
arg.description: Maximum number of seconds between reports.

arg.name: reportableChange
arg.description: Amount of change to trigger a report.

command.description: Create a expect-report-from-me message with associated values.

arg.name: cluster
arg.description: The cluster id for the requested report.

arg.name: attributeId
arg.description: The attribute id for the requested report.

arg.name: timeout
arg.description: Maximum amount of time between reports.

command.description: Sets the direction for global commands, either client to server or server to client.

arg.name: direction
arg.description: The direction for global commands, 0 = client to server, 1 = server to client.

command.description: Create a Discover Commands Generated command with associated values.

arg.name: clusterId
arg.description: The cluster to find commands on.

arg.name: startCommandId
arg.description: The command id to start the command search on.

arg.name: maxCommandId
arg.description: Max command ids to search for.

command.description: Create a Discover Commands Received command with associated values.

arg.name: clusterId
arg.description: The cluster to find commands on.

arg.name: startCommandId
arg.description: The command id to start the command search on.

arg.name: maxCommandId
arg.description: Max command ids to search for.

command.description: Sets a flag so that the application framework WILL respond to the next ZCL message that comes in over the air.
Sets a flag so that the application framework WILL NOT respond to the next ZCL message that comes in over the air.
This is a command used for testing that generates an attribute read command which requests so many attributes that the returned response is fragmented.
Prints the current mode of the test harness.

This turns on indication that the specified cluster requires APS security. This does not override the normal rules by the SE profile for security. It simply supplements the rules with one additional cluster that requires APS security.

arg.name: clusterId
arg.description: The cluster to be turned on requiring APS security.

command.description: This turns off indication that the specified cluster requires APS security. This does not override the normal rules by the SE profile for security. It simply supplements the rules with one additional cluster that requires APS security.
Turns on automatic Smart Energy Registration after joining or reboot. Default is on.
Turns off automatic Smart Energy Registration after joining or reboot. Default is on.
Sets normal mode for key establishment on the test harness, which suppresses any bad behavior and allows normal KE operation.

The device will send a "Terminate Key Estabilshment Message (No resources)" in response to any attempt to initiate KE with it. As a client, it will send a Terminate message after receiving the Initiate Key establishment response.

The device will send a "Default Response (Failure)" in response to any attempt to initiate KE with it. As a client, it will send a Default Response after receiving the Initiate Key establishment response.

This command will send an out-of-sequence message during key establishment. It will look for the local device to send the command with the passed 'ID' and will send a different command ID. So if the outgoing command is Initiate KE (ID 0) and the passed ID = 0, then it will send an Ephemeral Data Command (ID 1) instead.

arg.name: commandId
arg.description: The command id that the test harness is looking for.

command.description: This command will induce a timeout by dropping the outgoing message instead of sending it. This will occur for every command, except when the device is a KE client sending the first message. In that case it will induce a timeout on the second message (ephemeral data request).

This command causes the test harness to introduce artificial delays to the ephemeral key and confirm key generation time. It will delay generation by 'delay-time-seconds' so it takes longer than normal. Thus the ephemeral data request/response message will be delayed. The 'advertised-delay-seconds' is the amount of time that the local device tells the partner it will take them (in the Initiate KE message). If the delay-time-seconds <= advertised-delay-seconds, then key establishment should complete successfully but just be delayed. If delay-time-seconds > advertised-delay-seconds then the partner device should timeout the operation as the local device will take longer than expected. However the local device will still send the ephemeral data message in an attempt to continue key establishment. It is expected that the partner will reject this attempt and send back a Terminate message.

arg.name: delayTimeInSeconds
arg.description: The number of seconds to delay.

arg.name: advertisedDelayInSeconds
arg.description: The advertised delay time in seconds.

command.description: This will modify the initiate key establishment message length by +/- 'signed-length' bytes.

arg.name: signedLength
arg.description: The number of bytes to add or remove on th einitiate ke message.

command.description: This will rewrite the issuer field of the certificate with the 'new-issuer-value' when the initiate key establishment message is sent out.

arg.name: newIssuerValue
arg.description: The new issuer value.

command.description: This will rewrite the subject field (EUI64) of the certificate with the 'new-subject-value' when the initiate key establishment message is sent out.

arg.name: newSubjectValue
arg.description: The new subject value.

command.description: This will rewrite the 'index' byte of the certificate field of the initiate key establishment message to corrupt the certificate. It will bit-flip the 'index' byte to change its value.

arg.name: index
arg.description: The new index byte of the certificate field.

command.description: This will change the policy of whether the TC allows new link keys into its table. Normally all devices are pre-configured in the TC with an install code and so the TC must have prior knowledge of the device in order to allow CBKE with it. However when running in the SE_TEST security mode the TC uses a global link key and so there is no prior knowledge.

arg.name: policyFlag
arg.description: New policy boolean value.

command.description: This will tell the price server whether or not it should send publish price commands with the new SE 1.1 fields: Number of Block Threshholds and Price Control. Defaults to TRUE.

arg.name: sendPublishPriceCmd
arg.description: New policy boolean value for the sending of publish price commands.

command.description: This command will cause the device to immediatley send a Trust Center Keepalive message.
Turn off the keepalive state machine so it does not periodically send keepalive messages.
Turn on the keepalive state machine so starts periodically sending keepalive messages.

This will mangle the image stored in the OTA Simple Storage RAM Driver. Only available when the OTA Simple Storage RAM driver plugin is enabled. This is really only useful in simulated testing. For testing on real hardware it is better to use a Linux box with a set of images, one of which is corrupted.
This command will set the key-update method to use unicast (as opposed to broadcast) to individually update devices with the new NWK key.
This command will set the key-update method to use broadcast (as opposed to unicast) to update all devices at the same time with the new NWK key.
Start the NWK key update process now.
Sets the two byte manufacturer specific identifier to use for the next command if the command is not already built.

arg.name: mfgSpecificId
arg.description: Manufacturer Specific Id

command.description: Cli command to call emberAfSetTime function documented in af.h

arg.name: utcTime
arg.description: ZigBee UTC time, number of seconds since the year 2000

command.description: Creates the payload for an over the air message that turns identifying on for a given endpoint and a given amount of time

arg.name: endpoint
arg.description: The endpoint on the device which should begin identifying

arg.name: time
arg.description: The number of seconds to spend identifying

command.description: Creates a message payload for a command that turns identifying off on a given endpoint.

arg.name: endpoint
arg.description: The endpoint on which to stop identifying

command.description: Sets the on-off value to on for the add scene command and sets the level control clusters level value also sent with the add scene command.

arg.name: level
arg.description: The level value to send with the add scene command

command.description: Sets the on-off value to off for the add scene command and sets the level control clusters level value also sent with the add scene command.

arg.name: level
arg.description: The value to send with the add scene command

command.description: Populate a buffer to send a static load control event with the following values: all device classes, all uegs, criticality level: normal, 1.1c cooling temp offset, 1.1c heating temp offset, cool temp set point 23.3c, heat temp set point, -10% avg load percent, duty cycle

arg.name: eventId
arg.description: 4 byte event id for the load control event

arg.name: start
arg.description: Start time for the load control event

arg.name: duration
arg.description: Duration for the load control event

arg.name: event control
arg.description: Control byte for the load control event

command.description: Send a sample whois command. This was used for testing and should be modified for production use.
Send a random amount of data through a tunnel to the server (used for testing)

arg.name: tunnel-id
arg.description: The two byte tunnel id

arg.name: length
arg.description: The two byte length of the random data to send

command.description: Send a random amount of data through a tunnel to the server (used for testing)

arg.name: tunnel-id
arg.description: The two byte tunnel id

arg.name: data
arg.description: data to transfer to the client

command.description: Send a random amount of data through a tunnel to the server (used for testing)

arg.name: tunnel-id
arg.description: The two byte tunnel id

arg.name: length
arg.description: the length of random data to send to the client

command.description: Send a pre-buffered message from a given endpoint to an endpoint on a device with a given short address.

arg.name: id
arg.description: short id of the device to send the message to

arg.name: src-endpoint
arg.description: The endpoint to send the message from

arg.name: dst-endpoint
arg.description: The endpoint to send the message to

command.description: Send a pre-buffered multicast message to a given group id from a given endpoint.

arg.name: groupId
arg.description: group id of the multicast group to send the message to

arg.name: src-endpoint
arg.description: The endpoint to send the message from

command.description: send using a binding based on the clusterId in the globalApsFrame and the srcEndpoint specified (if the src endpoint is zero it only sends based on the clusterId)

arg.name: srcEndpoint
arg.description: source endpoint to send a binding based message from

command.description: This sends a read attr for the time of the device specified. It sets a flag so when it gets the response it writes the time to its own time attr

arg.name: id
arg.description: two byte short id of the time server

arg.name: srcEndpoint
arg.description: source endpoint to send time sync from

arg.name: destEndpoint
arg.description: destination endpoint to expect response on

command.description: Creates a message by specifying the raw bytes. Use "send" to send the message once it has been created. Ex: raw 0x000F {00 0A 00 11 22 33 44 55} sends a message to cluster 15 (0x000F) of length 8 which includes the ZCL header.

arg.name: clusterId
arg.description: two byte cluster id

arg.name: data
arg.description: two byte short id of the time server

command.description: send an interpan message to a group id.

arg.name: groupId
arg.description: group id to send to

arg.name: destPan
arg.description: destination pan id

arg.name: destprofileID
arg.description: destination profile ID

command.description: Send an interpan message to a short id. Static data used is as follows: interpan commands mac is : [FC 2; seq 1; dest PAN 2; dest addr 2|8; src pan 2; src addr 8] stub nwk is: [Frame Control 2] stub APS is: [FC 1; groupId 0|2; clusterId 2; appProfileId 2] MAC FC = bits 0,1,2: frame type (Data) 1 bit 3: security enabled = false (0) bit 4: frame pending = false (0) bit 5: ack required = true (1) bit 6: intra PAN = false (0) bit 7,8,9: reserved (0) bit 10,11: dest addr mode = group (1), short (2), long(3) bit 12,13: reserved (0) bit 14,15: src addr mode = long(3) for GROUP_DEST FC is: 0xC421 for SHORT_DEST FC is: 0xC821 for LONG_DEST FC is : 0xCC21 Stub NWK FC: bits 0,1: frame type 3 (0b11) bits 2-5: protocol version 2 (0b0010) bits 6-15: reserved (0) this is always 0x000B stub APS FC: bits 0,1: 3 (0b11) bits 2,3: delivery mode unicast(0), bcast(2), group(3) bit 4: reserved (0) bit 5: security: none (0) bit 6: ack request: NO ack (0) bit 7: ext header present: No (0) this is 03 for unicast, 0B for bcast, 0F for group

arg.name: shortId
arg.description: group id to send to

arg.name: destPan
arg.description: destination pan id

arg.name: destprofileID
arg.description: destination profile ID

command.description: Send an interpan message to a long address (8 byte eui64)

arg.name: longId
arg.description: long ieee address to send the interpan message to

arg.name: destPAN
arg.description: two byte destination PA ID

arg.name: destProfileID
arg.description: two byte destination profile ID

command.description: Read an attribute from the local attribute table. The attribute is displayed on the command line.

arg.name: endpoint
arg.description: endpoint of the attribute to read

arg.name: cluster
arg.description: cluster id of the attribute to read

arg.name: attribute
arg.description: attribute id of the attribute to read

arg.name: mask
arg.description: direction mask of the attribute to read (client=0 or server=1)

command.description: Write an attribute value into the local attribute table

arg.name: endpoint
arg.description: endpoint of the attribute to write

arg.name: cluster
arg.description: cluster id of the attribute to write

arg.name: attribute
arg.description: attribute id of the attribute to write

arg.name: mask
arg.description: direction mask of the attribute to write (client=0 or server=1)

arg.name: dataType
arg.description: the attribute type as listed in the generated file attribute-type.h

arg.name: dataBytes
arg.description: string of bytes you wish to write into the attribute table.

command.description: Gives information about the local node
Lists which optional libraries of the stack are implemented on this device
Enable the printing of received messages.
Disable the printing of received messages.
Initiates Smart Energy Registration including Key Establishment. This command expects that the device has already joined a smart energy network.
Sends a ZDO Match Descriptor Request for the server side of the specified cluster from the specified application profile. Match Descriptor Responses received are printed to the serial output.

arg.name: profileId
arg.description: the profile id to send with the discovery message

arg.name: clusterId
arg.description: cluster id to send with the discovery message

command.description: Sends a ZDO End Device Bind Request using the given local endpoint.

arg.name: endpoint
arg.description: The local endpoint whose simple descriptor will be used to create the request

command.description: Prints out the binding table to the command line.
Clear the binding table
Set a binding table entry for the arguments specified.

arg.name: bindingTableIndex
arg.description: one byte index into the binding table

arg.name: clusterId
arg.description: cluster id to send with the discovery message

arg.name: localEndpoint
arg.description: local endpoint to bind

arg.name: remoteEndpoint
arg.description: remote endpoint to bind

arg.name: ieeeAddress
arg.description: 8 byte IEEE address provided big endian

command.description: Prints the address table.
Set an entry in the address table according to the arguments specified

arg.name: addressTableIndex
arg.description: one byte index into the address table

arg.name: ieeeAddress
arg.description: IEEE address to enter into the address table

arg.name: nodeId
arg.description: two byte node id to enter into the address table

command.description: Executes the associated command as defined in the emberAfCustomCommands array of type EmberCommandEntry
Forces the AppFramework to set/clear the APS Retry option (in APS Frame options mask) for all subsequent outgoing messages; Turns APS retry on.
Forces the AppFramework to set/clear the APS Retry option (in APS Frame options mask) for all subsequent outgoing messages; Turns APS retry off

Forces the AppFramework to set/clear the APS Retry option (in APS Frame options mask) for all subsequent outgoing messages; a value of "default" allows the AppFramework to use its own default logic to determine when the APS Retry option should be used.
Turns aps security off
Turns aps security on
Sets a link key in the link key table. Example: option link 0x00 { 06 00 ab 41 64 30 00 0a } {aa bb cc dd ee ff aa bb cc dd ee ff aa bb cc dd}

arg.name: keyTableIndex
arg.description: index into the link key table

arg.name: ieeeAddress
arg.description: IEEE address to enter into the link key table

arg.name: linkKey
arg.description: link key to enter into the table

command.description: Derives a link key from an install code and sets it in the link key table.

arg.name: keyTableIndex
arg.description: index into the link key table

arg.name: ieeeAddress
arg.description: IEEE address to enter into the link key table

arg.name: installCode
arg.description: install code including two-byte, little-endian CRC

command.description: Clear all security keys
Print all security keys out to the command line.
Delete a security key from a given index

arg.name: index
arg.description: index into the security key table

command.description: A test command which solicits an attribute read which will force the responding node to send a response that uses fragmentation.
Print the attribute table.
Print out the time information
Prints out the current settings for debug printing on the device
Turns on all compiled in debug printing
Turns off all debug printing
Turns on compiled in debug printing for a specific debug printing area. Debug print areas are defined in the generated <application>.h header file.

arg.name: area
arg.description: The debug area mask listed in the <application>.h file

command.description: Turns off compiled in debug printing for a specific debug printing area. Debug print areas are defined in the generated <application>.h header file.

arg.name: area
arg.description: The debug area mask listed in the <application>.h file

command.description: Shows the version of the software
Prints out values for tracked stack counters
Prints out the cli command options for the device
resets the device
Turns echo on the command line on or off depending on the argument

arg.name: echoOn
arg.description: boolean indicating whether to turn echo on (1) or off (0)

command.description: Used on a Unix based gateway or large host to sync current time known to the application with Unix time known to the host.
Create a network on the given channel, power and panId.

arg.name: channel
arg.description: The channel on which to form the network

arg.name: power
arg.description: One byte signed value indicating the TX power that the radio should be set to

arg.name: panId
arg.description: Two byte pan id for the network

command.description: Join an existing network on the given channel, power and panId.

arg.name: channel
arg.description: The channel on which to form the network

arg.name: power
arg.description: One byte signed value indicating the TX power that the radio should be set to

arg.name: panId
arg.description: Two byte pan id for the network

command.description: Rejoin an existing network in a secure or insecure manner.

arg.name: haveCurrentNetworkKey
arg.description: Boolean indicating whether the device can rejoin secure or not. 1=rejoin with encryption, 0=rejoin without encryption

arg.name: channelMask
arg.description: 4 byte channel mask which should be used to search for the network to rejoin.

command.description: Leave the current network.
Permit joining on the network for a given number of seconds

arg.name: seconds
arg.description: Number of seconds during which devices will be allowed to join the network. A value of 0xff turns permit joining on permanently

command.description: Permit joining on the network for a given number of seconds AND broadcast a ZDO Mgmt Permit Joining request to all routers.

arg.name: seconds
arg.description: Number of seconds during which devices will be allowed to join the network. A value of 0xff turns permit joining on permanently

command.description: Write the extended pan id for the device.

arg.name: extPanId
arg.description: The bytes for the extended pan id

command.description: Begins a search for an unused Channel and Pan Id. Will automatically form a network on the first unused Channel and Pan Id it finds.
Begins a search for a joinable network. Will automatically attempt to join the first network that it finds.
Attempts to change device over to a different channel given in the channel argument

arg.name: channel
arg.description: The channel to change to.

command.description: Set the network index used by all future CLI commands. Before executing a CLI command, the framework will switch to this network. After the command finishes executing, the framework will switch back to the previous network. The CLI uses the same network index until the device resets or it is changed through this command.

arg.name: networkIndex
arg.description: The network index to use for CLI commands

command.description: Change the link key to the one provided in the 16 byte array argument for this command.

arg.name: key
arg.description: The link key provided as a 16 byte array

command.description: Change the network key to the 16 byte array provided as an argument to this command.

arg.name: key
arg.description: The network key provided as a 16 byte array

command.description: Start the Certificate Based Key Exchange process.

arg.name: partnerId
arg.description: The short address of the device with which to start cbke

command.description: Perform Certificate Based Key Exchange over interpan

arg.name: panId
arg.description: The 2 byte pan id of the partner with whom to start cbke

arg.name: ieee
arg.description: The ieee address (EmberEUI64) of the partner with whome to start cbke

command.description: Add clusters to the known server (in) clusters on this device.

arg.name: clusterIds
arg.description: Array of two byte server cluster ids

command.description: Clear the ZDO list of server (in) clusters.
Add clusters to the known client (out) clusters on this device.
Clear the ZDO list of client (out) clusters.
Sends an update channel request.

arg.name: channel
arg.description: One byte channel to change to.

command.description: Performs an energy scan.

arg.name: targetNodeId
arg.description: Two byte short id of the target device

arg.name: scanDuration
arg.description: One byte scan duration. Must be in range 0 - 5

arg.name: scanCount
arg.description: Number of scans to perform. Must be in range 1 - 8

command.description: Sends a set network manager request for the given network manager node id and active channels provided in the 4 byte channel mask.

arg.name: nwkMgrId
arg.description: Two byte network manager id

arg.name: channelMask
arg.description: Four byte channel mask

command.description: Sends a network address request for the given IEEE address.

arg.name: ieee
arg.description: IEEE address for which a short address is being requested

command.description: Request an ieee address based on a given node id.

arg.name: nodeId
arg.description: Short address of the device for which a long address is requested

command.description: Sends out a simple descriptor request for the short address and endpoint specified.

arg.name: dest
arg.description: Short address of the device where the simple descriptor request should be sent

arg.name: targetEndpoint
arg.description: The endpoint on the target device where the simple descriptor request will be sent

command.description: Sends a node descriptor request to a given target device

arg.name: target
arg.description: Two byte address for the target device.

command.description: Sends a matchDescriptorsRequest to the given destination with the given profile.

arg.name: nodeId
arg.description: Two byte node id indicating wher

arg.name: profile
arg.description: Two byte profile id for the match descriptor request

command.description:
Send a ZDO Bind command to a device specified in the command arguments.
NOTE: For simple bind requests, just put {} as the last argument More complex requests, you can actually specify the dest EUI64 the binding, which is NOT the same as the EUI64 of the destination of the device receiving the binding. This allows for a user to set multiple bindings on the destination for different devices.
NOTE: The source/dest EUI are relative to the context. In the case of the syntax of the CLI, we take "THEIR EUI64" to mean the recipient of the binding request message. However, when sending the bind request that EUI64 used by the ZDO command is actually the source for the binding because we are telling the remote device (the destination) to create a binding with a source of itself. And the destination for that binding will be this local device. This is also not to be confused with the (short) destination of the ZDO request itself.

arg.name: destination
arg.description: Two byte destination node id

arg.name: localEndpoint
arg.description: Local endpoint to bind

arg.name: remoteEndpoint
arg.description: Remote endpoint to bind

arg.name: cluster
arg.description: Cluster on which to bind

command.description: Send an active endpoint request to the device with the given short id.

arg.name: nodeId
arg.description: Two byte short id, destination for the active endpoint request
